text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This transmits revised IRM 9.7.9, Equitable Sharing and Reverse Asset Sharing.

9.7.9.3.3(1) is updated to correct the reference to Executive Office for Asset Forfeiture to Treasury Executive Office for Asset Forfeiture (TEOAF). All subsequent references to have been changed to TEOAF.
9.7.9.6.5(1) is updated to state that sharing in adoptive seizures is prohibited.
Additional revisions, deletions, and grammatical changes were made throughout the section that did not result in substantive changes but contributed to procedural clarity of the subject matter.
EFFECT ON OTHER DOCUMENTS

This IRM supersedes IRM 9.7.9, Equitable Sharing and Reverse Asset Sharing dated August 11, 2008. This IRM also incorporates procedure(s) implemented by the Director, Operations Policy and Support, guidance memorandum dated April 16, 2015, [Subject: “Additional Guidance on TEOAF Directive No 34-Policy Limiting the Federal Adoption of Seizures by State and Local Law Enforcement Agencies”].

) One of the goals of the Department of the Treasury Asset Forfeiture Program is to encourage joint operations among Federal, state, and local law enforce- ment agencies, as well as foreign countries. The equitable sharing program has proved invaluable in fostering enhanced cooperation among Federal, local, and foreign law enforcement agencies. (

) The Department of the Treasury Guide to Equitable Sharing for Foreign Countries and Federal, State, and Local Law Enforcement Agencies contains policies and procedures applicable to the sharing of assets that are seized forfeited by Treasury law enforcement agencies. This Guide was designed only for the Treasury law enforcement agencies, but for any Federal, state, local law enforcement agency that files an equitable sharing request with a Treasury law enforcement agency. (
) IRM

, Equitable Sharing and Reverse Asset Sharing, closely follows the format of and contains excerpts from the Guide, which should be referred to needed for additional or more detailed information. Each Asset Forfeiture dinator (AFC) should have a copy of the Guide for their own use and an additional supply to provide to agencies submitting equitable sharing with Criminal Investigation (CI). (
) This section will also cover reverse asset sharing which is the single largest source of funding for CI’s law enforcement initiatives. (
) Federal law establishes the authority of the Secretary of the Treasury to federally forfeited property with participating Federal, state, and local law en- forcement agencies. (

) The intent of Congress in the sharing of forfeited property, as stated, is to ensure that any property shared with a law enforcement agency: a. Has a value that bears a reasonable relationship to the degree of direct participation to the law enforcement effort resulting in the forfeiture, into account the total value of all property forfeited and the total law en- forcement effort with respect to the violation of law on which forfeiture is based; and b. Will serve to encourage further cooperation between the recipient and Federal law enforcement agencies. (

) Any Federal, state, or local law enforcement agency, or foreign country, that directly participates in an investigation or prosecution that results in a federal forfeiture by a Treasury law enforcement agency may request an equitable share of the net proceeds of the forfeiture. (

) If the forfeiture is completed by a Treasury law enforcement agency, then another Treasury law enforcement agency cannot apply for an equitable of the proceeds unless the request is for tangible or real property. Monetary instruments cannot be shared between Treasury law enforcement agencies. (

) US Attorney offices are not eligible to receive Treasury equitable sharing, however, state and local prosecutor offices that directly participate in an tigation or prosecution that results in a Treasury Federal forfeiture are eligible to receive Treasury equitable sharing. Refer to the Guide for examples of in which state and local prosecutors may qualify for an equitable share.
Sharing and Reverse Asset Sharing 9.7.9 page

One of the goals of the Department of the Treasury Asset Forfeiture Program is to encourage joint operations among Federal, state, and local law enforce- ment agencies, as well as foreign countries. The equitable sharing program has proved invaluable in fostering enhanced cooperation among Federal, local, and foreign law enforcement agencies.
The intent of Congress in the sharing of forfeited property, as stated, is to ensure that any property shared with a law enforcement agency:

a. Has a value that bears a reasonable relationship to the degree of direct participation to the law enforcement effort resulting in the forfeiture, taking into account the total value of all property forfeited and the total law en

forcement effort with respect to the violation of law on which forfeiture is based; and b. Will serve to encourage further cooperation between the recipient agency and Federal law enforcement agencies.

) The Office of Inspector General, US Department of Agriculture (OIG/USDA), the Department of Justice (DOJ), the US Postal Service, and the Sharing with of the Treasury entered into a Memorandum of Understanding to establish of Inspector participation of OIG/USDA in the DOJ Asset Forfeiture Program and DOJ United States Forfeiture Fund for forfeitures after May

As a participant in the of Asset Forfeiture Fund, OIG/USDA is eligible to file for equitable shares that correspond to their degree of participation in law enforcement efforts in forfeitures by Treasury law enforcement agencies. In addition, OIG/USDA allowed, by statute, to file petitions for remission for
percent of the proceeds of the forfeited assets as a victim. (

) To prevent a situation of duplicate filing for equitable sharing and a petition remission by OIG/USDA, which results in a loss to the Treasury Forfeiture Fund, the Warrants and Forfeitures Section should be consulted on how to proceed when a field office is working with OIG/USDA in a joint that involves forfeiture where CI is the seizing agency, and anticipates that OIG/USDA will file for equitable sharing. ) There are two ways in which to participate in the equitable sharing through a joint investigation or the adoption of a Federal or foreign seizure. Ways to Participate Equitable Sharing (

) Joint investigations are those in which Treasury law enforcement agencies work with other Federal, state, or local law enforcement agencies, or Investigation countries, to enforce Federal criminal laws. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

(08-13-2003) Equitable Sharing with the Office of Inspector General, United States Department of Agriculture
There are two ways in which to participate in the equitable sharing program; through a joint investigation or the adoption of a Federal or foreign seizure.
Sharing and Reverse Asset Sharing 9.7.9 page
) Adoptive seizures are only those seizures where

percent of the pre- seizure activity was performed by the seizing agency. Seizures resulting from Federal, joint investigations or task force investigations are not adoptive seizures. or Foreign and local agencies generally request Federal adoption when, after making a seizure, they determine that a state forfeiture proceeding is not possible or a Federal forfeiture proceeding would be more advantageous. (
) There must be a state violation and a Federal basis for forfeiture in order for the seizure to be classified as an adoption. (
) The TEOAF Directive Number

, Policy Limiting the Federal Adoption of Seizures by State and Local Law Enforcement Agencies, sets general policies and procedures with respect to adoptions and covers the federal adoption form, Request for Adoption of State or Local Seizure (Exhibit
), investigative agency review and approval, time period to request an adoption, notice requirements, and retention of custody by state or local agency. Directive Number

is summarized as follows: Federal adoption of state and local seizures is prohibited except for property that directly relates to public safety concerns, including firearms, ammunition, explosives, the instrumentali- ties of child pornography, adulterated food products, counterfeit consumer goods and similar items that pose a public health and safety concern. The hibition on federal adoption includes, but is not limited to, seizures by state or local law enforcement of vehicles, valuables, and cash. Cash is defined as currency and currency equivalents, such as postal money orders, personal cashier’s checks, stored value cards, certificates of deposit, traveler’s checks, and U.S. savings bonds. Any other property that may trigger the public safety exception may be adopted federally with the Director of TEOAF’s approval through the Director of Warrants & Forfeiture. Equitable sharing is prohibited any federal adoption. This does not impact joint investigations and does not apply under the following circumstances:

Adoptive seizures are only those seizures where 100 percent of the pre- seizure activity was performed by the seizing agency. Seizures resulting from joint investigations or task force investigations are not adoptive seizures. State and local agencies generally request Federal adoption when, after making a seizure, they determine that a state forfeiture proceeding is not possible or that a Federal forfeiture proceeding would be more advantageous.

a. Seizures by state and local authorities working together with federal au- thorities in a joint task force b. Seizures by state and local authorities that are the result of joint federal- state investigations or that are coordinated with federal authorities as of ongoing federal investigations c. Seizures pursuant to federal seizure warrants, obtained from federal courts to take custody of assets originally seized under state law In the rare instance of an adoption of seized property that raises a public safety concern, CI will continue to follow the procedures set forth in IRM

), which requires a legal review of the adoption by a Criminal Tax (CT) attorney and that a seizure warrant be obtained prior to taking custody any assets seized by a state or local agency. In any instance where CI wishes to adopt a state or local seizure of property that it believes implicates public safety but is NOT listed in the previous paragraph (
), approval must be obtained by the Director of TEOAF through the Director of Warrants & Forfeiture prior to taking possession using the following process:
) SAC prepared memo to Director of TEOAF, through Director of Warrants & Forfeiture;

After the seizure in a joint investigation, a Federal, state, or local agency may request a share of the property by submitting a Form TD F 92–22.46, Request for Transfer of Property Seized/Forfeited by a Treasury Agency, to CI. Exhibit 9.7.9–3 contains Form TD F 92–22.46 and supplemental instructions.

Sharing and Reverse Asset Sharing 9.7.9 page

) The Director, Treasury Executive Office for Asset Forfeiture (TEOAF) makes the ultimate decision whether and how much to share after review and approval by the Department of State. No United States representative has statutory authority to commit to asset sharing in any given case until an national forfeiture sharing agreement has been approved at the delegated levels of the Department of the Treasury (or Justice) and State. (

) A foreign country may request a share of the property by contacting the US Embassy or country attache' via a letter of request. The embassy should forward the letter of request to the appropriate field office. (
) Equitable sharing requests should be submitted within
days after the date of seizure. The

–day rule may be waived by the Director, Warrants and for Filing an feitures, upon a written request stating the reasons that justify a waiver for Sharing late submission of the equitable sharing request. The request for a waiver must accompany the Form TD F

) The date of seizure is generally the date the property is physically seized taken into custody by CI. This is also true for criminal forfeitures where property is not seized until the court enters a preliminary order of forfeiture. the case of a civil judicial forfeiture involving real property or other property seized until a final judgment or order of forfeiture is entered, the date of seizure is the “post and walk” date or the date the warrants of arrest in rem are executed. (

) For property that is seized as evidence, the date of seizure for forfeiture is generally the evidence seizure date or the initial date when action is taken to commence forfeiture proceedings against the property. (
) In civil or criminal judicial forfeitures, an agency may amend its Form TD F
within
days after forfeiture to reflect any continued participation the case. (
) No equitable sharing request will be considered after two years from the the forfeited property is disbursed, deposited into the Treasury Forfeiture or otherwise disposed of. (

) A lack of adequate communication between Treasury law enforcement agencies and the requesting agencies often leads to ill will and confusion of and the equitable sharing process. In order to remedy this situation, TEOAF Equitable developed sample letters that are used to keep requesting agencies advised the status of their equitable sharing request, while providing them with a contact name and telephone number of an agency representative who can furnish them with timely information regarding their equitable sharing These letters are contained in TEOAF Directive Number

, Equitable Acknowledgments and Advice on Sharing Requests. Warrants and will send these letters to the requesting agencies after the equitable sharing requests are submitted for Headquarters/CI approval. (

) Forfeiture, like all legal proceedings, takes time. Equitable sharing may occur only after the Federal forfeiture has been completed, the United States has taken clear title to the property, and a final sharing decision has been made the appropriate official. Common causes of delay are listed in the Guide. (
) Internal Revenue Manual

Equitable sharing requests should be submitted within 60 days after the date of seizure. The 60–day rule may be waived by the Director, Warrants and For- feitures, upon a written request stating the reasons that justify a waiver for the late submission of the equitable sharing request. The request for a waiver must accompany the Form TD F 92–22.46.
(07-28-2015) Acknowledgments and Advice on Equitable Sharing Requests
) Equitable sharing is based on the net proceeds of the forfeiture. Net are calculated as follows: Gross receipts from forfeiture or the sale of the Equitable Share forfeited property, less: (cid:
) qualified third party interests (cid:
) CI investigation-related expenses (cid:
) restitution/remission to victims through the petition process (cid:
) any award paid to a federal informant regarding the asset (cid:
) Treasury property management expenses (cid:
) any reimbursements from the Treasury Forfeiture Fund to the requesting agency that relate to the particular seizure equals net proceeds available for equitable sharing. (
) Generally, the Federal share will not be less than
percent. (

) In cases where only a single item of tangible property (e.g., a vehicle) is forfeited and a Federal, state or local agency, or foreign country requests Sharing item rather than proceeds from the sale of the property, the Treasury a Single Item Fund must recover its costs and its equitable share. If the requesting Property unable to pay the costs and equitable share, the property shall be sold and proceeds equitably distributed according to the formula in the previous paragraph. Exceptions to this requirement will be conservatively granted by Warrants and Forfeitures upon written assurances that: a. the requesting agency lacks funds or authority to make such payments and/or b. the forfeited item will fill a demonstrated need of the requesting agency (

) Where real or tangible personal property is transferred to a state or local enforcement agency, the value of that property shall be charged against of agency’s equitable share or other assets in the investigation. Where there Costs insufficient other assets against which to charge that share, the recipient or local law enforcement agency must compensate the Treasury Forfeiture Fund for the Federal share and costs. (

) If the requesting agency is unable to pay the costs of the Federal share, property shall be sold and the proceeds equitably distributed. The Director, Warrants and Forfeitures may grant exceptions when: a. the property will be transferred to a state or local unit of government, or through such agency, to a private non-profit organization to support abuse treatment, drug and crime prevention and education, housing job skills programs, or other community-based programs; or b. the requesting state or local agency lacks funds or authority to make payments, and the forfeited property will fill a demonstrable need of the requesting agency (

) Federal law mandates that sharing in joint investigations reflects the degree direct participation of the requesting agency in the law enforcement effort in Joint resulting in the forfeiture. Normally, this is determined by comparing the number of investigative hours expended by the requesting agencies. The worked include all hours worked by investigators or professional analysts technicians through the completion of the forfeiture directly attributed to the forfeiture action. Secretarial and support staff time may not be used in an Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

Federal law mandates that sharing in joint investigations reflects the degree of direct participation of the requesting agency in the law enforcement effort resulting in the forfeiture. Normally, this is determined by comparing the number of investigative hours expended by the requesting agencies. The hours worked include all hours worked by investigators or professional analysts and technicians through the completion of the forfeiture directly attributed to the forfeiture action. Secretarial and support staff time may not be used in an

page agency’s determination of investigative hours. The final determination of sharing percentages will not be done until after the property has been and all of the participating agency’s total contributions to the have been determined. (

) The following additional factors will be considered where the hours devoted not adequately reflect the degree of participation of the requesting agency: a. Did the agency originate all of the information leading to the seizure? b. Did an agency provide unique and indispensible assistance? c. Could the state or local agency have achieved forfeiture under state law, but joined forces with the United States/CI to conduct a more effective vestigation? (
) For examples of situations that may apply to the questions listed above, refer to the Guide. (

) Many task forces involving Federal, state, and local law enforcement have agreed equitable sharing arrangements based upon relative numbers of personnel and other contributions to the task force operation. These pre- agreed percentages will be honored when: a. the agreement is generally consistent with the Department of the equitable sharing policy b. the agreement is in writing c. the decision-maker is satisfied that the percentages agreed upon to reflect the true overall agency contributions to the task force d. the task force has a well defined subject area or organization target as focus and, the specific seizures are part of the overall investigative function of the task force (
) Refer to the Guide for more information regarding a formal chartered task force, multi-agency cases, and task force agreements. (
) Sharing in adoptive seizures is prohibited. (

) All forfeiture cases involving foreign equitable sharing requests must be approved by the Director, TEOAF, and the Department of State. Internal Revenue Manual

) To ensure agencies receiving equitable sharing from CI are properly thanked for their participation and to encourage future joint efforts, the SAC will send of Equitable letter to the receiving agency or make a formal presentation to the receiving agency, depending on the circumstances. (

) If the SAC elects to personally present an equitable sharing check to the re- questing agency official, the AFC should ensure the Disposition Instructions sent to TEOAF include in the additional comments section a request that the equitable sharing check(s) be sent to the AFC for presentation. (
) The Treasury Executive Office for Asset Forfeiture (TEOAF) will notify the office when equitable sharing payments are sent to the requesting electronically. (
) The Guide provides detailed guidance to requesting agency’s permissible impermissible uses of equitable shared property. Equitably Property (
) The Treasury Executive Office for Asset Forfeiture (TEOAF) Directive

, Weed and Seed Initiative; Transfers of Real Property, describes the Weed Seed Initiative and Seed Initiative and explains how federally forfeited real property may be transferred to state and local public agencies and private non-profit tions for use in support of the Weed and Seed Initiative. (

) Weed and Seed is an initiative designed to reclaim and rejuvenate neighborhoods and communities. Weed and Seed uses a neighborhood focused two-part strategy to control violent crime and to provide social and economic support to communities where high crime rates and social ills are prevalent. The initiative first removes or “weeds” violent criminals and drug dealers from the neighborhoods. Second, the initiative prevents a of criminal activity by “seeding” the neighborhoods with public and private- services, community-based policing, and incentives for new businesses. (
) The requirements of the Weed and Seed Initiative are as follows: (cid:

) A state or local law enforcement agency that contributed to an that resulted in the forfeiture of real property may only request the as a Weed and Seed asset sharing. The intent should be to use such property for Seed purposes or to transfer it to a public or private recipient for the same Seed purposes. (cid:

) The ultimate non-profit recipient must be an appropriate non-profit zation, which agrees to use the property in compliance with the Weed Seed Initiative. If the property ceases to be used for its intended for a specified time period, the non-profit recipient agrees that title may revert to the United States. (cid:
) Any state or local agency with a claim to an equitable share of the must agree to waive any claims to sharing in the property or its proceeds deference to the Weed and Seed request. (cid:
) A Form TD F

must be submitted by the requesting state or agency to CI identifying the property to be transferred to a non-profit nization pursuant to the Weed and Seed Initiative. Input from the United States Attorney is recommended.
The Guide provides detailed guidance to requesting agency’s permissible and impermissible uses of equitable shared property.

tions for use in support of the Weed and Seed Initiative. Weed and Seed is an initiative designed to reclaim and rejuvenate embattled neighborhoods and communities. Weed and Seed uses a neighborhood focused two

part strategy to control violent crime and to provide social and economic support to communities where high crime rates and social ills are prevalent. The initiative first removes or “weeds” violent criminals and drug dealers from the neighborhoods. Second, the initiative prevents a reinfestation of criminal activity by “seeding” the neighborhoods with public and private
services, community
based policing, and incentives for new businesses.
The requirements of the Weed and Seed Initiative are as follows: (cid:

The intent should be to use such property for Seed purposes or to transfer it to a public or private non-profit recipient for the same Seed purposes. (cid:

If the property ceases to be used for its intended purposes for a specified time period, the non-profit recipient agrees that title may revert to the United States. (cid:

) A Form TD F

must be submitted by the requesting state or local agency to CI identifying the property to be transferred to a non-profit orga- nization pursuant to the Weed and Seed Initiative. Input from the Assistant United States Attorney is recommended.

(cid:
) All outstanding and future liens, taxes, repairs, maintenance, etc., must paid by the recipient or other agency and may not be paid by the Forfeiture Fund. (cid:

) Upon approval of the request by CI, the Weed and Seed request must be submitted to TEOAF. This package should include, at a a letter from the requesting agency explaining the use for the property, waiver agreements from the other participants, and Equitable Sharing Decision Form, TD F
(Exhibit

), and a letter or dum from CI requesting approval from the Director, TEOAF. The letter memorandum should describe the request in detail and indicate the US Attorney’s Office concurs with the request. (

) All participating state and local law enforcement agencies must implement standard accounting procedures and internal controls to track equitably monies and tangible property in accordance with the general accounting dures and compliance requirements contained in the Guide. Appendix D of Guide contains sample bookkeeping procedures that will meet this require- ment. (

) Department of the Treasury policy requires that state and local law enforce- ment agencies submit the reports described in the following paragraphs to TEOAF at: Treasury Executive Office for Asset Forfeiture
G Street NW,
th Floor Washington, DC
Fax: (

) Federal Equitable Sharing Agreement -- As a prerequisite to participating the Department of the Treasury Equitable Sharing Program, a state or local law enforcement agency must submit a signed Federal Equitable Sharing Agreement to TEOAF. The head of the law enforcement agency and a nated official of the governing body must sign this agreement, which is submitted every three years on or before October
Federal agencies are exempt from this requirement. A sample of this agreement is contained in Appendix C of the Guide. (
) Federal Annual Certification Report -- State and local law enforcement agencies must also submit a Federal Annual Certification Report to TEOAF within

days following the close of the agency’s fiscal year, which also be signed by the head of the law enforcement agency and a designated of the governing body. A sample of this agreement is contained in Appendix of the Guide. (
) Annual Audit -- Audits will be conducted as provided by the Single Audit Amendments of
and OMB Circular A-
Audits of States, Local ments and Non-Profit Organizations. (

) Non-compliance with the policies of the Guide, including the failure to submit the Federal Equitable Sharing Agreement and Annual Certification Reports, may subject recipient agencies to sanctions. (
) The sanctions include one or more of the following: a. Denial of an agency’s sharing request Internal Revenue Manual

) Upon approval of the request by CI, the Weed and Seed request package must be submitted to TEOAF. This package should include, at a minimum, a letter from the requesting agency explaining the use for the property, waiver agreements from the other participants, and Equitable Sharing Decision Form, TD F
(Exhibit

), and a letter or memoran- dum from CI requesting approval from the Director, TEOAF. The letter or memorandum should describe the request in detail and indicate whether the US Attorney’s Office concurs with the request.

) All participating state and local law enforcement agencies must implement standard accounting procedures and internal controls to track equitably shared monies and tangible property in accordance with the general accounting proce- dures and compliance requirements contained in the Guide. Appendix D of the Guide contains sample bookkeeping procedures that will meet this require- ment.

) Criminal Investigation and other Treasury law enforcement agencies routinely participate in joint investigations where a DOJ law enforcement agency is the Sharing lead seizing agency. The lead seizing agency processes the seizure through forfeiture to disposition. (
) In order for CI to receive its equitable share of the forfeited property resulting from its participation in the investigation, CI must file a Form DAG-
with DOJ law enforcement agency performing the seizure. This procedure is as reverse asset sharing. Forms DAG-
are available from the DOJ law en- forcement agency. (

) Like the Department of the Treasury, DOJ has an asset forfeiture fund into which forfeited cash and proceeds from the sale of property forfeited by a law enforcement agency are deposited. The DOJ Asset Forfeiture Fund essentially the same purposes and is subject to most of the same as the Treasury Forfeiture Fund. The DOJ Asset Forfeiture Fund policy a maximum asset sharing amount of
percent. (

) The funds due the Treasury Forfeiture Fund from reverse asset sharing are important to the overall management and effectiveness of the fund. In order the Treasury Forfeiture Fund to effectively monitor reverse asset sharing and achieve successful financial management of reverse asset sharing, TEOAF issued Directive Number
, Policy for the Filing of DAG-
for Reverse Sharing. (

) It is the responsibility of CI, and other Treasury law enforcement agencies, to file a request for an equitable share of forfeited property resulting from gations in which CI participated with DOJ law enforcement agencies. (
) Reverse asset sharing requests (Forms DAG-
) must be submitted to the DOJ seizing agency within
calendar days of the seizure. The

-day rule can be waived only upon a written request provided to the DOJ seizing agency, stating the reasons for the late submission of the request and/or providing justification for the waiver. In those circumstances where CI’s principal contribution occurs after the seizure, but during the period of time in which the forfeiture is being perfected, it would be appropriate to request a waiver to the
-day rule or to amend a previous request. Failure to adhere these rules may result in delayed or lost shares to the Treasury Forfeiture Fund. (
) CI, and other Treasury law enforcement agencies, must report the filing of Forms DAG-
within
days of the date of seizure by sending a copy of Form DAG-
, by mail or facsimile, to: Reverse Asset Sharing Desk Treasury Executive Office for Asset Forfeiture

) The SAC must approve seizure investigative activities through CIMIS for investigation where CI participates in the seizure and forfeiture activity DOJ law enforcement agency, and all reverse asset sharing requests reported on the Asset Forfeiture Tracking and Retrieval System See IRM
, Forms, Processing, and Documentation. (

) The AFC should use AFTRAK to monitor open reverse asset sharing In some instances, the seizing agency may issue a letter notifying CI of status of the sharing request. However, in most instances, no notification received. It is the responsibility of the AFC to periodically obtain a status update by contacting the seizing agency. (

) If CI is denied the ability to apply for equitable sharing by a DOJ law ment agency, or fails to receive an equitable share in return for their participation, the responsible Supervisory Special Agent (SSA) or SAC couraged to attempt resolution at the field office level. If resolution cannot achieved, the issue should be forwarded to TEOAF, through the Warrants Forfeitures Section, for resolution at the Treasury/Justice level. (

) Tangible property received from a Federal agency through reverse asset sharing may be placed into official use in accordance with CI guidelines. Forfeited cash and proceeds from the sale of forfeited property must be deposited to the Treasury Forfeiture Fund. (
) Reverse asset sharing checks must be forwarded immediately to TEOAF a completed Form #
, Deposit Information (Exhibit
), and a copy related Form(s) DAG-

) Federal agencies do not have the authority to accept equitable shares of property or tangible items from state, local, or foreign law enforcement agencies. Such shares have to be treated as gifts to the Federal and permission to accept the gift must be sought from Treasury’s Secretary (Management) before accepting any such property.

The SAC must approve seizure investigative activities through CIMIS for any investigation where CI participates in the seizure and forfeiture activity with a DOJ law enforcement agency, and all reverse asset sharing requests must be reported on the Asset Forfeiture Tracking and Retrieval System (AFTRAK).

Federal agencies do not have the authority to accept equitable shares of property or tangible items from state, local, or foreign law enforcement agencies. Such shares have to be treated as gifts to the Federal government and permission to accept the gift must be sought from Treasury’s Assistant Secretary (Management) before accepting any such property.

Sharing and Reverse Asset Sharing 9.7.9 page 17
Instructions for Completing Treasury Form 92-22.46

A separate TD F 92-22.46 must be completed for each seizure, unless the investigation or en- forcement action resulted in multiple seizures, then one TD F 92-22.46 may be filed with a of the seizures.

The deadline for submitting the TD F 92.22-46 to the Treasury investigative agency processing the seizure/forfeiture is 60 days from the date of seizure. Only in extraordinary circumstances will a TD F 92.22.46 be considered if submitted after the deadline.

In some instances the Agency must return costs and the appropriate Treasury agency equitable share to the Treasury Forfeiture Fund. If the Agency is unable to return the costs and Treasury share, the property will be liquidated and the proceeds distributed proportionally. (Upon justification exceptions may be granted by the deciding official.)
Instructions
For Treasury use only.

Provide the agency’s name, address and NCIC code. If the NCIC code is not known, contact the Treasury investigative agency responsible for processing this forfeiture. The contact person is the person who has authority to accept property and transfer and/or money.

Provide as complete a property description as possible. Include serial or vehicle identifica- tion number. You must check either “Item ”(if requesting an asset) or “Cash/Proceeds” (if requesting a percentage of the asset). Attach a list of any other asset(s) seized in this case.
Exhibit 9.7.9-3 (Cont. 3) (07-28-2015) Form TD F 92–22.46 and Supplemental Instructions, Request for Transfer of Property Seized/Forfeited by a Treasury Agency

If “Cash/Proceeds” is requested, provide the percentage of the net proceeds requested the agency. The percentage requested must be based on the degree of direct or indirect law enforcement effort by the federal, state or local agency resulting in the seizure forfei- ture, taking into account the total value of all property forfeited and total law enforcement effort, including any related criminal prosecution with respect to the violation of law on the forfeiture is based.

Indicate the specific intended law enforcement purpose(s) for the requested cash, proceeds or tangible property. Pursuant to the Guidelines, all property, including cash and proceeds, must be used for the specific law enforcement purpose(s) approved.
